Description: Costco Wholesale agreed to pay $11.75 million to settle allegations that its pharmacies violated the Controlled Substances Act when they filled prescriptions for controlled substances that were incomplete, lacked valid Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) numbers or were for substances beyond various doctors' scope of practice.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/costco-wholesale-pay-1175-million-settle-allegations-lax-pharmacy-controls

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 42499: Other Miscellaneous Nondurable Goods Merchant Wholesalers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Costco Wholesale Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, agreed to cut its emissions of ozone-depleting and greenhouse gases from leaking refrigeration equipment at more than half of its stores nationwide. In the settlement announced by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and U.S. Department of Justice, Costco will pay $335,000 in penalties for federal Clean Air Act violations and will fix refrigerant leaks and make other improvements at 274 of its stores, which EPA estimates will cost about $2 million over the next three years.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/united-states-settles-costco-cut-ozone-depleting-and-greenhouse-gas-refrigerant-emissions

Description: Racial retaliation. The verdict was upheld in 2007 by the 3rd Circuit in ruling nos. 05-5134 and 06-1690.
Info Source: https://digitalcommons.law.villanova.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=2679&context=thirdcircuit_2007

Description: The case alleged that Costco discriminated against women in choosing general managers and assistant general managers. The company agreed to create an $8 million fund to pay claims by class members  and subsequently agreed to pay $3.95 million in attorneys' fees and $933,959 in costs.
Info Source: https://www.lieffcabraser.com/employment/costco/
https://www.cpsc.gov/Newsroom/News-Releases/2019/Costco-Agrees-to-3-85-Million-Civil-Penalty-Compliance-Program-for-Failure-to-Report-Defective-Trash-Cans

Private Litigation Case Title: Dittmar v. Costco Wholesale Corporation et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/936155/costco-inks-9m-deal-to-end-calif-pharmacists-ot-suit
http://www.terrellfcrasettlement.com/

Description: Costco and JBR agreed to jointly pay $500,000 in settlement of allegations by 25 California District Attorneys that they sold plastic coffee pods with misleading marketing claims related to biodegradability and compostability. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided equally between them.
Info Source: https://www.alcoda.org/newsroom/2018/mar/costco_and_sf_gourmet_coffee_settlement#more

Description: Costco agreed to pay $3.6 million in settlement of allegations by local prosecutors' offices throughout the state that it violated state law concerning the storage, handling and disposal of items sold and used at its stores that were hazardous waste.
Info Source: https://www.alcoda.org/newsroom/2012/jun/costco_settlement_environmental_action#more
